intro: Coronopus incisus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved coronopus, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the family Violaceae, which includes violets and related species. The plant is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges. Its flowers are typically violet-blue in color, with five petals and a distinctive spurred structure. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks.
